high_relevance.description: Examines relationships and information flows through network structures, including concepts like strong/weak ties and centrality
high_relevance.relevance_to_rqs: Directly addresses RQ1 by explaining how network position and social capital accumulation affect progression from periphery to core
high_relevance.relevance_to_model: Can model network metrics (centrality, density) as stocks influencing knowledge access and promotion likelihood
high_relevance.phd_contribution: Quantifies social capital's role in OSS career progression; bridges social structures with learning pathways

high_relevance.description: Theory of human motivation focusing on autonomy, competence, and relatedness as key drivers of sustained engagement
high_relevance.relevance_to_rqs: Addresses RQ1 motivational gaps and RQ2 intervention design by identifying what sustains participation through career stages
high_relevance.relevance_to_model: Can model motivation as stock influenced by autonomy, competence, and relatedness feedback loops
high_relevance.phd_contribution: Explains motivational transitions across career stages; informs motivation-sensitive intervention design

high_relevance.description: Conceptualizes trade-offs between short-term velocity and long-term quality as accumulating 'debt' that requires future payment
high_relevance.relevance_to_rqs: Directly addresses RQ3 by explaining how quality erosion and vulnerabilities emerge from development process trade-offs
high_relevance.relevance_to_model: Can model technical debt accumulation and interest payments as stocks and flows affecting system reliability
high_relevance.phd_contribution: Links developer progression patterns to systemic quality outcomes; explains vulnerability emergence pathways

adjacent_opportunities.description: Explains how newcomers learn values, norms, and behaviors needed to assume organizational roles
adjacent_opportunities.why_adjacent: While focused on formal organizations, provides structured framework for understanding OSS community entry processes
adjacent_opportunities.novel_angle: Brings formal socialization tactics (collective vs individual, formal vs informal) to informal OSS contexts
adjacent_opportunities.phd_contribution: Systematizes the 'unwritten rules' of OSS participation; provides taxonomy of socialization mechanisms

adjacent_opportunities.description: Organization's ability to recognize, assimilate, and apply new external knowledge
adjacent_opportunities.why_adjacent: Shifts focus from individual learning to community-level knowledge processing capabilities
adjacent_opportunities.novel_angle: Treats OSS communities as learning systems with varying capacity to absorb newcomer contributions
adjacent_opportunities.phd_contribution: Explains why some communities better integrate newcomers while others reject contributions; community-level learning dynamics

adjacent_opportunities.description: Argues that some complex, tightly-coupled systems are prone to inevitable 'normal accidents'
adjacent_opportunities.why_adjacent: Originally for high-risk technologies, but provides lens for understanding inevitable vulnerabilities in complex OSS
adjacent_opportunities.novel_angle: Frames OSS vulnerabilities as emergent properties of complex, interdependent systems rather than individual failures
adjacent_opportunities.phd_contribution: Provides theoretical foundation for why certain OSS architectures may be inherently vulnerable despite good processes

cross_domain_inspiration.parallel: OSS communities as ecosystems undergoing succession from pioneer to climax states
cross_domain_inspiration.transfer_potential: Predictable patterns of community maturation, niche specialization, and stability/vulnerability trade-offs
cross_domain_inspiration.rationale: Provides powerful metaphors for understanding long-term community evolution and resilience patterns

cross_domain_inspiration.parallel: Apprentice-journeyman-master progression systems in craft guilds
cross_domain_inspiration.transfer_potential: Formalized skill transmission, quality control mechanisms, and reputation-based advancement
cross_domain_inspiration.rationale: Historical precedent for structured skill development in decentralized, reputation-based systems

cross_domain_inspiration.parallel: How organizations like air traffic control maintain safety in complex, high-risk environments
cross_domain_inspiration.transfer_potential: Principles of redundancy, deference to expertise, and sensitivity to operations for vulnerability prevention
cross_domain_inspiration.rationale: Despite different context, offers proven strategies for managing complexity and preventing catastrophic failures

phd_strategy.rationale: These three theories directly address the major gaps in each research question while being empirically grounded and modelable in system dynamics. They provide complementary perspectives at individual, social, and technical levels.
phd_strategy.integration_strategy: Use Social Network Theory to model relationship pathways in RQ1, Self-Determination Theory to inform motivation-sensitive interventions in RQ2, and Technical Debt Framework to connect development processes to quality outcomes in RQ3. All can be integrated with existing Communities of Practice framework.
phd_strategy.expected_impact: Creates a comprehensive multi-level theory explaining how individual motivations, social structures, and technical decisions interact across the OSS developer lifecycle, enabling more effective interventions and vulnerability prevention.
